title: 108_s501
content: The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" establishes a grant program for gifted and talented students under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This program authorizes activities to support gifted and talented students. The "Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003" recognizes the need for specialized services for gifted students from diverse backgrounds, including those with disabilities or English as a second language. It highlights that elementary school gifted students often master a significant portion of the curriculum before the school year begins. Teachers are faced with a diverse range of student traits and needs. Most teachers receive training to meet the needs of diverse students, but often lack training for gifted students. Public schools are crucial for providing services to high-ability students, especially those from disadvantaged backgrounds. Gifted education programs in public schools are essential for equal educational opportunities, with parents and families playing a vital role as partners. Gifted education programs in public schools are crucial for providing equal educational opportunities to approximately 3,000,000 gifted and talented students. While some states allocate resources for these programs, others do not, leading to a disparity in services. Parents and families are essential partners in developing appropriate educational services for gifted students. State laws and funding for gifted education vary widely, leading to disparities in services for gifted students. It is crucial for more students to achieve higher levels of education to meet future economic and national security needs. The performance of advanced students in the US on international studies is among the lowest in the world. In the study, US physics and advanced mathematics students performed poorly compared to other countries. Funding for gifted education in the US was minimal in 1990. Grants are available for developing gifted education programs. The Secretary may award grants to State educational agencies for developing gifted education programs and providing educational services to gifted students. Grant funds can be used for various activities, including direct educational services and materials for gifted students. The grant funds provided under this chapter can be used for direct educational services and materials for gifted and talented students, such as curriculum compacting, modified curriculum, acceleration, independent study, and dual enrollment. However, the funds cannot be used for purchasing or upgrading technological hardware. Additionally, a State educational agency receiving a grant under this chapter is limited to using no more than 10 percent of the funds for dissemination of program information and providing technical assistance. The State educational agency can use grant funds for direct educational services for gifted students, but not for technological hardware. Only 10 percent of the funds can be used for dissemination of program information and technical assistance. Administrative costs are limited to 50 percent of the funds. "SEC. 5467A. ALLOTMENTS TO STATES." From the amount available for this chapter, the Secretary reserves funds for programs in schools operated or funded by the Bureau of Indian Affairs. The remaining funds are allotted to states based on their population of individuals aged 5 through 17, with a minimum grant amount set. Any unclaimed allotments are reallocated to other states. "SEC. 5467B. STATE APPLICATION." To be eligible for a grant under this chapter, a State educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary with specified assurances, including using funds to support gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, making grants to local educational agencies, and ensuring funds supplement, not replace, state and local funds for gifted education. The State educational agency must provide matching funds for activities under this chapter, ensure program assessment for accountability and effectiveness, and have their application approved by the Secretary to receive funds. The State educational agency must allocate at least 90 percent of funds to local educational agencies through a competitive process for grants to carry out authorized activities. Grants must meet the needs of students served. Local educational agencies must submit an application to the State educational agency to receive a grant for identifying and supporting gifted and talented students from diverse backgrounds, including training personnel and ensuring funds supplement existing resources. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires annual reporting by State educational agencies on the number of students served and activities supported with funds. Recipients can serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs. Grants must ensure equitable participation of private school students and teachers. Definitions are provided in the Act. The Gifted and Talented Students Education Act of 2003 requires annual reporting by State educational agencies on the number of students served and activities supported with funds. Recipients can serve gifted students alongside those with similar needs. Definitions for terms like 'gifted and talented' and 'State' are provided in the Act. Authorization of Appropriations: $170,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2004-2010. $7,500,000 for Chapter A and the remainder for Chapter 2. Technical amendments made to the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. In Chapter A of the Jacob K. Javits Gifted and Talented Students Education Program, amendments were made to sections 5461 and 5464 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. This included changing references from "this part" to "this chapter" and redesignating subsections within section 5464.
